projects.name: Caring Turtlebot (CT-bot): A Step Towards Affordable Assistive Robotics
projects.description: The Caring Turtlebot (CT-bot) project aims to develop an affordable assistive robot to aid healthcare professionals by automating routine tasks, such as delivering items within medical facilities. Utilizing advanced computer vision and natural language processing algorithms, CT-bot is designed for non-expert users, enabling seamless human-robot interaction through simple voice commands. The system involves creating semantic maps of indoor environments, recognizing room and facility signs, and navigating autonomously while avoiding obstacles. Tested at the University of Maryland's Iribe Center, the CT-bot demonstrates reliable task execution, enhancing efficiency and reducing workload for healthcare providers.

projects.name: Who's deceiving? An investigation into making multi-agent coordination robust to adversarial spoofing.
projects.description: The project explores the robustness of multi-agent systems against adversarial attacks. Focusing on a multi-robot rendezvous problem, the study investigates how a malicious agent can disrupt the coordination of benign agents aiming to converge at a common point. Using reinforcement learning (RL), specifically policy gradients and Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) techniques, the research develops an undetectable malicious agent capable of delaying the convergence of benign agents. Implemented in an OpenAI Gym environment, the project utilizes neural networks to train the malicious agent to maximize its disruptive potential while appearing benign. Through extensive experimentation, the study demonstrates the effectiveness of RL in creating resilient adversarial strategies, contributing valuable insights into the security challenges of multi-agent systems. The project highlights the intersection of robotics, machine learning, and cybersecurity, paving the way for future research on safeguarding multi-agent coordination.

projects.name: Interactive Visualization and Clustering of COVID-19 Case Data
projects.description: The project aims to create a web-based tool that provides dynamic visualizations of COVID-19 cases and deaths across the United States. Utilizing data from the New York Times and the United States Census Bureau, the tool leverages Python and Dash by Plotly to allow users to interact with and analyze COVID-19 trends at the county level. The project incorporates machine learning, specifically k-means clustering, to group counties with similar case rates, offering a deeper understanding of the pandemic's progression. Users can explore daily and cumulative case trends, compare county clusters, and make informed decisions based on the visualized data.
